review_title: Needs improvement in change culture & systems, but a great place
pros: ACDI/VOCA has been going through a lot of change the past few years, from the needed layoff to other restructurings. While the company needs to get *much* better at announcing and rolling out systems and changes, I have been here over five years and this is a great place with some of the most dedicated people I’ve worked with. Other places in the industry handle change well, and their employees react to most announcements with a curious and upbeat outlook.  ACDI/VOCA’s change culture here needs a complete overhaul.
cons: (same text as my Pros above) - ACDI/VOCA has been going through a lot of change the past few years, from the needed layoff to other restructurings. While the company needs to get *much* better at announcing and rolling out systems and changes, I have been here over five years and this is a great place with some of the most dedicated people I’ve worked with. Other places in the industry handle change well, and their employees react to most announcements with a curious and upbeat outlook.  ACDI/VOCA’s change culture here needs a complete overhaul.

review_title: Great Mission with Major Organizational Issues
pros: Like many on who have replied, the mission of the organization is what we work for. People have dedicated much of their professional lives to achieving that mission, and will keep doing so. Benefits and work/life are great, way too much sick leave to even figure out how to use.
cons: This organization is at a crossroads. Finally a COO was hired outside the organization, but much of the success will depend on the authority the COO is able to have. A restructure is mandatory as the current system has failed. Far too many "VPs" with no actual responsibility has created a culture of complacency. A lot of junior staff leave as there are no real opportunities for advancement, and promotions are too few at the lower ranks.

review_title: Re-energized and moving in the right direction (and fast)
pros:
Take the negative reviews with a grain of salt.  This organization is pushed forward by its talented and dedicated staff and strong leadership that's about to get even stronger.   The COO brought new energy and focus.  She had to make some tough decisions but managed to create an open and positive environment in the midst of a tightening market.   New Biz VP is streamlining new business operations - a few recent wins prove that it's working.  

Junior and mid-level staff get plenty of opportunity to travel and develop new skills, although they are also the ones working the longest hours to fit it all in.  

And you can't beat the benefits.
cons:
There is some internal dysfunction that sometimes holds things back.  Heavy new business workload.  Junior and mid-level staff tend to leave when there is no room for them to grow (however, this is not uncommon for this industry). 

A limited selection of good restaurants and HH options in the area. :)

pros: The company has great learning opportunities and encourages staff to take advantage of them. They seem to understand the importance of work-life balance. They are generally friendly people who are great to work with. They have a great onboarding program for new employees that I have no seen at any other job.
cons: The company seems to be going downhill. Recent changes have left employees frustrated, and many people who have been there for a long time are leaving. There seems to be a pattern of putting people in high positions that they are not qualified for, which hurts the people working under them. I would've given this organization a 5 at one point. Changes in leadership at the organization and department levels have made a big dent in how I view the organization.

pros: Nice, smart co-workers who are dedicated to the organization's mission. Travel opportunities for junior-level staff. Nice office space. Generally managers are good with having a work/life balance. Good benefits and location.
cons: There used to be a better trajectory for internal promotion of high-performing, junior- and mid-level staff. Now many high-performers have to leave to advance their careers. Some senior managers seem to be more concerned with keeping the status quo rather than advocating for their staff to develop within their roles and advance their careers. There seems to be an inner circle of senior staff who take lightly serious concerns raised repeatedly by junior- and mid-level staff. Some senior staff are located in roles that are not their strengthens or areas of expertise, leading to challenges in decision making.

review_title: Seeds for change being planted now will reap long-term benefits
pros: As you may read from some of these other posts, it's no lie that ACDI/VOCA has been through a lot over the past few years. However, former CEO (and CEO listed here as of the time of this posting, it's outdated) has been out as of December 2017, which is a good thing. COO/Interim CEO has been doing a great job since then--very accessible and transparent--and I am optimistic about the new CEO coming in June/July based on feedback from interviews that have occurred. New Head of Business Development is whipping the department back into shape, helping bring about a few interesting new wins and adding to cautious optimism.
cons: Working on new business can feel relentless.

review_title: Fast moving upstart organization in International Development
pros:
Employees are passionate about their work.

Transparency in how they operate.

Good leadership team which communicates well to the employees.

Support for employees to seek out development opportunities and for employees to have a real work/life balance.

Senior management is focused on "controlled growth", which shows that they have an eye to ensuring the long-term success of the organization.
cons:
Promotions above mid-level can be a bit difficult to come by. 

Junior and mid-level staff have fairly high turn-over, but this is common in the international development business.

Need more systems set in place for both project management and new business. They are getting there, but still have a ways to go. 

There needs to be more communication between the technical portfolios. Activties can sometimes overlap and there could be more knowledge sharing of best practices.

review_title: A competent development contractor with lots of growth opportunities
pros:
Great opportunities for advancement; the organization is growing rapidly and they make an effort to promote from within. Smart hardworking people will move up quickly.

Friendly atmosphere and decent work-life balance. You will work hard here, but it is not as cut-throat at some other contractors. 

Staff with MAs and several years of experience will get opportunities for field postings, with a little luck.
cons:
HQ staff are largely involved in project administration and new business. Though there are many technical experts, there are few exclusively technical roles outside of field positions. 

Can be travel intensive

Business systems and processes are not always as developed as they should be for an organization of this side. A lot of flying by the seat of your pants, but this is typical for most NGOs.

review_title: Use to be a great organization.
pros: The organizational culture at the time was strong and staff were great to be around.
cons:
The HR department was too big for the amount of staff and was segregated, everyone specialized in a different areas and were not willing to cross train or to teach others.  One would be pigeon hold in your particular role and would not allow for any advancement opportunities.  

Also, Senior Leaders were interested in pursuing a more flexible work schedule, however when requested to work from home, they were not interested and advised staff that it was not acceptable.  

Since my tenure, the company has undergone some major changes.   At the end of 2014, a new CEO took over and laid off about 10% of the workforce.   From my understanding since then, it is still not a good time to join the organization.

review_title: Interesting work, poorly executed project implementation and poor senior leadership
pros: ACDI/VOCA does interesting work and provides opportunities for junior level staff to travel.
cons: The organization does not promote innovation or recognize junior level staff. They put high expectations on lower level staff but do not give them the appropriate pay or title. I am honestly surprised by the good reviews written by current/former employees as I do not know a single person that works here that truly enjoys it. Overall, the office environment is toxic and for the past year and a half employees have been leaving the company left and right. For a good period of time someone was resigning every week, some with no jobs lined up and just wanting out. Furthermore, I have had serious ethical issues with how projects are managed. I often times feel as though employees and senior management are not truly concerned for the poor and it shows in the projects. I would not recommend this company to any of my friends.

pros: Great Work Life Balance.  Has a number of good people working.  Excellent training ground for young people starting out in the international development field.  Lots of opportunities to travel and a very relaxed atmosphere.
cons: Not a great place for people of color.  The accounting and the human resources offices have the most diversity. It is one of the most frustrated places to work.  No matter what you do, if you are not in the Senior Management crowd, you will not get promoted.   It used to be a very mean-spirited organization; I am not sure if the culture has changed.

review_title: My program's unqualified, insecure COP doomed the team's work
pros: In theory, should be making the world a better place...
cons: Current and former employees of the Colombia program where I worked see the COP as a boy sent to do a man's job: ineffective, unable to delegate, and (understandably) insecure about his abilities to do the job. The mass non-renewal of staff contracts in 2017 was seen as another symptom of his insecurity--a bid to surround himself with friends and sycophants who would coddle and never question him. Without exception, those who have left the program (and I include myself in this group) say they are delighted to no longer be there and shudder when they back on the toxic atmosphere and meager achievements that have characterized the current COP's tenure.

pros: ACDIVOCA has been a good organization with the support of HQ-IT Department in giving me assigned task in helping to enhance my skills and expertise in handling server as Administrator using Hyper-V (Vsphere), Office 365, Sharepoint, Quickbooks Enterprise and so on. With the need for staff development, ACDIVOCA has created account for all IT staff with cbtnuggets in enhancement and the discharge of the IT responsibilities in each and every office globally.  The Management team has a good working relationship with their staff as it relates to respect, mentoring, and coaching.
cons: Management team at HQ-Washington needs to see more reasons and improvement on staff benefits which is causing project in Liberia to have more staff resigning.

review_title: New Leadership, Positive Changes & Renewed Spirit
pros:
Organization is committed to positive change, growth, and learning.

New leadership in the organization has led to improved morale, some terrific hires and re-hires, and improved policies.  The COO really shines.  Her work ethic is tremendous and she has played a pivitol role in reshaping the organization into one committed to collaboration, operational excellence, and providing new opportunities for all staff, with a special focus on supporting women in leadership development.

We're awaiting the release of a strategic plan, led by our new CEO.

Great mission, solid benefits, more opportunities, and a lot of smart, passionate, caring colleagues keep me here.
cons: Long hours when on proposals can be tough.  Some policies could continue to be simplified and improved.

pros: The work that ACDI/VOCA does is great. This company strives to better lives around the world by implementing agricultural projects in under-developed countries, which is largely the reason I work here.
cons: The most toxic environment I have ever worked in. All employees seem miserable and over 10 people have resigned in the last 2 months. This company is going down fast. The management treats its entry and mid level employees terribly, with little to no room to grow within the company. ACDI/VOCA has a very catty and gossipy work environment, which I'm sure isn't unique to this company, however, it does make for a miserable work week. I dread going to work on Monday morning at this company.

pros: A strong history of working in agricultural development around the world. ACDI/VOCA is developing new tools and restructuring to better implement development projects.
cons: Over the past year, ACDI/VOCA has restructured, gotten a new CEO and put in place new processes and practices. While some of this is good, the organization seems to be prioritizing uber compliance over good development and seems to no longer trust its employees. As a result, many feel disempowered and frustrated with changes they don't always understand. In addition, the organization does not seem to be sincerely interested in improving its own operations. For example, no exit interviews are done with departing employees to learn their reasons for leaving and try to improve those areas of the employee experience.

pros: Working here is very interesting, you learn new things every day and it challenges your ability to perform on different issues related to your work. There are time based procurement and issues and the people I work with are very good at what they do.
cons: Most of the work are very bulky and the demand on time to complete them are very short. There are a lot of policies and procedures to be followed and a lot of conditions to be met before procurement are carried out.

review_title: Great company, lots of opportunities to grow.
pros: The people are fantastic, and the culture is very positive, with an emphasis on collegiality and personal growth. You will learn the ins and outs of USAID project implementation and most likely have the opportunity to travel. The management structure is fairly transparent, giving employees the chance to express concerns. Lots of professional development opportunities for self-starters.
cons: Like many companies in international development, there is a heavy emphasis on winning new business with USAID and other donors (not necessarily a negative, depends on your perspective). Sometimes support staff contributions are undervalued.

review_title: Great company with poor corporate level leadership and management
pros: I loved working for ACDI/VOCA for the years that I was at the company. The work that I did while there was engaging and I always felt good about the actual job itself. The company does (or did - losing staff regularly) have great staff with great experience who support each other well. Benefits are much better than those offered by other companies. In general, there is a camaraderie among its staff that helps to make it a great place to work at day in and day out.
cons:
That said, there are a lot of issues right now. The corporate level leadership and management is severely hurting the company's outlook and staff morale. Mr. Polidoro and his team make seemingly haphazard decisions that have significant consequences not only for those left trying to implement these poor policies or structures but also for the project management of these programs themselves. "Reimaginings" of project management did not take staff feedback into account and ignored the legitimate issues that their staff have in operating on a day to day basis. 

Because of these issues with management, the company is losing staff who were dedicated to the mission, experienced and great at their jobs. Loss of that historic knowledge and investment is huge and the company will feel that for a while.

review_title: Good learning experience for junior employees, management is mixed
pros: The organization is good about providing opportunities to junior staff to move up and to travel once they prove themselves.  Having a good manager who will advocate for you is critical.  The organization is also growing, which provides a lot of opportunities to work on new projects.
cons: Management can be a bit inconsistent, and it can be difficult to understand the overall organizational strategy.  There is also a lot of turnover at the junior level, but this is common in the industry.

pros: Great opportunities for travel and experience if you demonstrate competency. On the technical side a strong group of senior staff with established reputations in the field and a depth and diversity of projects in the portfolio. Internal management systems could be better, but are still ahead of other organizations in the field that I have worked for.
cons: Very conservative management which is risk and change averse. This can lead to slow adaptation to the changing field of international development. Experiences from practice area to practice area can vary widely in terms of satisfaction.

review_title: A Lot of Change Indeed and It's All Bad
pros: Unfortunately there are none any longer.
cons: The organization is devoid of empathy at the senior level. Junior staff continue to be overlooked and overworked while long serving employees are thrown under the bus to rectify massive overhead concerns which the senior team are responsible for.

pros: I value working at a place that is mission driven and generally like the majority of my colleagues. Junior-level staff are incredibly hardworking as are the majority of project managers and technical staff. Benefits are generous to make up for lower than average salary (especially at the more junior to mid-level positions).
cons: Management at all levels of ACDI/VOCA is abysmal. I had high hopes that changing the structure of the executive management team by bringing in external candidates would be a good change. These individuals are more of the same and seem to adopt the same management style as existing leaders, leading to very little actual change. Moreover, there's a real attitude of senior staff to disregard the talents, aspirations, and feelings of more junior or mid-level staff. This company brings in very bright project assistants and coordinators with master's degrees and fluency in at least two languages and then provides them with no real room to grow and completely overworks them. While the company has a gender policy and strives to promote diversity, I cannot begin to recount the number of times I've felt overlooked or exploited because of my status as a more junior person in my role. Having been here for the better part of 4 years, I've seen the organization continue to struggle with the same issues over and over, with little to be seen in the way of results. I'm not sure I'll be able to stay with the company for much longer given the way things continue to progress.

pros: Large enough organization to work in almost any country and almost any sector. Salary and benefits packages are highly competitive. Was once an industry leader in agribusiness and food security.
cons: Senior management tends to lack focus and is inconsistent in organizational strategy. Cronyism at the senior and mid levels. Company culture is increasingly difficult for minorities. This was once a great place to work, but not headed in a different direction.

pros: Great benefits!  Lots of opportunities for trainings and professional development.
cons: Senior management does not care to consider contrary points of view.  Preferential treatment only goes to those who agree or who portray that they agree.  Such is the shortfall of current leadership that has done a laudable job of stabilizing operations, investing in systems and positioning for growth....which will be constrained due to current management style.

review_title: A once amazing organization coming apart at the seams under the strain of inadequate leadership and a changing market
job_title: Senior Manager, Program Management in Washington, DC
pros: some flexibility but it's fading fast as the organization continues to shed staff and suffer the effects of brain drain.  Nice office space with and open floor plan that should inspire collaboration but seems to have had the opposite effect as it really just underscores the lack of staff and those left feel exposed and vulnerable to scrutiny.  Short commute for anyone on or along the red line as it's directly opposite Union Station but I think I may be drawing at straws there.  There's still a small amound of brand left that can be used to leverage a new position when needed.
cons: Multiple unnecessary layers of senior leadership with minimal value added (but they do seem to know how to party though).  Lack of downward communication from senior management on organizational goals and priorities unless your part of the senior leadership club.  Lack of clear vision on new business development and bizarre allocation of financial resources by the incoming CEO directed toward hiring more executives, most of whom are friends and former colleagues from the past.  Weak project management system led by even weaker managers which is resulting large scale failures within existing programs and creating challenges on the financial management side as well.  You will likely be reading about them in the news like the former AED at some point in the near future.  There has been little if any interest in developing leadership within the organization and as a result the brightest young minds are leaving while the few good managers are also on their way out.  This used to be an amazing place for young people that were hungry and wanting to learn the business while working in a truly mission driven environment but for them it's little more than a sweatshop now with it's only real value is the brand they can use to market themselves to other organizations.  Sadly that brand is also dissolving.  They are still reeling from a 20% reduction in staff a  year ago and it sounds like another, though smaller may be in the works now.
